segments.Text:
This text was transcribed using whisper model: large-v2

 Welcome everyone, this is the Innocent State actor Shoosh, a look from the other side of
the fence, and I am Anastasios.
Before I start, a big disclaimer that everything I'm going to be talking about today is my
personal research and my personal views, it doesn't represent my employer by any means.
And hopefully that will be clear as I'm going through the presentation.
The goal of this talk is to make all of us better threat researchers by improving how
we see the other side of the fence.
Typically this is called red team thinking, which is thinking like the adversary, but
the whole theme of my talk is to better understand how nation state actors operate.
Now on why me?
The simpler question compared to what I have here would be the people that have the really
in-depth knowledge and experience in this space are not allowed to talk about it.
And in my case, because of this background and especially my interest in espionage history
allowed me to talk with some of these people, and lately we also had a lot of leaked content
from different agencies around the world.
So all of that combined was the sources that result in the presentation I'm going through
today.
The agenda is pretty simple.
First of all, I will start with the signals intelligence to make sure that we all speak
the same language.
And then I'm going to talk about two specific use cases, looking at them from the nation
state actor perspective.
The first one is what happens when certain tools get leaked or threat research is published.
And the second part is when we're talking about attribution, it is kind of different
if you are a nation state actor versus a cyber security company.
And I'm going to go into depth in that space, but to give you an idea, if you are officially
as a country saying that another country did some sort of cyber activity against your nation,
you have to be way more certain that an attribution will be used in a less critical manner.
So let's start with SIGINT or signals intelligence.
SIGINT has two components.
The first one is the ELINT.
We're not going to touch anything in this space, this is only for awareness, but ELINT
is information derived primarily from electronic signals that do not contain speech or text.
Typically here we're talking about intercepting like the signals that radars produce, certain
kinds of weapons and so on.
This is beyond our scope in this presentation.
However, the second part of SIGINT is the COMINT, which is communications intelligence.
In this case, what we are after is any sort of intelligence that has to do with speech,
text, or general communication.
And of course, cyber activity falls under that since we use the cyberspace to communicate,
whether this is systems communicating to each other or people communicating, all of that
falls under COMINT, which eventually falls under SIGINT.
And this is why you see SIGINT agencies doing all of the cyber operations.
Now how does it work from a very, very high level?
In every country you have some head of state and if you have multiple agencies doing signals
intelligence, you might even have copies of what I'm talking about here in different sectors.
For example, you might have a separate organization for military intelligence, a separate one
for foreign intelligence, and so on.
But those key stakeholders are going to be defining what are the national security policies.
And what do I mean by this one is, okay, who do we consider to be our enemy, our ally,
and the countries in between?
And those are going to drive the SIGINT organization on their objectives and prioritization.
What the SIGINT organization is going to do is take those and translate them to PIRs,
to priority intelligence requirements.
For example, for the enemies it could be, we want to know everything about them.
For the allies it could be, okay, we might want to validate that one thing or two that
they have said if it's actually true.
And for those nations in between it might be, well, we don't really trust them so we
need to keep an eye on everything they're doing that might have a relation to our goals.
In practice this translates to SIRs, specific information requirements, which is what are
the specific pieces of information we need to answer those priority intelligence requirements.
And all of that goes into the organization departments that mainly consist of the collection,
analysis and production, and dissemination.
Something that happens in this stage is that throughout all of this process there might
be certain things that happen that need additional information.
Those are typically referred to as the EEIs, or essential elements of information, and
those are for events of interest.
Let's say for example that a foreign nation is going to have some elections recently and
that is something that the heads of state are very interested in, but we don't have
this information.
After all of that is done and the analysis is produced, then the dissemination happens
back with the stakeholders and this is a continuous cycle that goes back.
This is not the traditional intelligence cycle but I intentionally did not include
the intelligence cycle here because I want to be more practical on how things work.
Now there is a difference between signals intelligence and counterintelligence, or CI.
Those are very important to understand to have a better view of those organizations
and how they operate.
In the intelligence side, how do you fulfill those PIRs is by collecting that information
or simply stealing it from whoever had access to those SIRs and EEIs.
The second part is you analyze all the available sources and then you produce a report, which
nowadays it could be anything, it could be actually a report, a printed report, electronic
reports, live dashboards that continuously update, podcasts, videos, anything you can
imagine.
But you produce an answer to those intelligence requirements and you share it back to your
customers and that could be, for example, what are the plans of country X with regards
to this, let's say, weapons deal.
Now the second part, which is very critical, equally critical, is the counterintelligence.
Here is what do the adverse SIRs do?
How are they attacking our nation in this case?
If we are doing those operations for intelligence collection, to monitor that they haven't been
compromised, for example, to monitor that no one has detected them, to monitor that
no one managed to steal the tools that they are using, and finally to find out who is
spying back on you.
In the cyberspace we focus a lot on the counterintelligence but we also need to not forget about the intelligence
collection.
Basically that clarifies all of the general terminology and the SIGINT organizations.
The next slide I'm going to be talking about what I have seen from all of the different
intelligence agencies I have studied so far in terms of the structures and I categorize
them to three very, very broad categories.
The first one is countries that have very limited cyber SIGINT capabilities.
We're talking about agencies that have anything from zero to ten people, typically they don't
operate in 24-7 but they might have some shift work if they are running some cyber operations
that requires around-the-clock operations.
Because of that, those countries typically have very limited technical expertise and
for this reason they cannot rely on in-house capabilities like building their own tools,
their own implants, their own exploits and so on.
So they rely heavily on third parties, that is companies that produce and sell those products
only to government agencies and you might have heard of some of them in the news.
I'm not going to name any companies over here, there are dozens of these companies.
But they also rely a lot on allied agencies.
What I mean here is that nation A might have very good relationships with nation B and
they know that nation B is in a more mature state so they ask them to perform some of
these operations or provide them with the tooling or expertise to do it on their own.
Then we go to the more of the basic SIGINT function countries and this is the majority
of the countries that exist today, where you have a couple of dozen of people dedicated
to cyber signals intelligence.
This one has pros and cons as you can imagine.
Typically in those countries they have some form of shift work for 24x7 coverage and from
one country to another varies a lot in technical expertise.
There are some countries that also have small teams, they are building exceptionally good
tooling and general capabilities but there are others that are more leaning towards the
first model where the teams are mostly on the operator side and less on the engineering side.
The good thing on this kind of size for these organizations is that they are very agile
and very flexible and that is easy to imagine.
You can literally have the entire cyber signals intelligence team sitting in a meeting room
agreeing on something and executing it.
For this reason they are moving faster and sometimes they are more efficient than the
larger organizations.
Typically in terms of tooling and capabilities they have this hybrid format that for certain
things they might build them in-house for certain tooling or capabilities.
For example they might have some really good malware analysts or reverse engineers or exploit
developers and they might be very good in these specific areas but for everything else
they are going to be relying on third parties and just like in the previous case allied
agencies play a key role.
The only difference in this stage is that there is a form of exchange so a bigger agency
might use some of the expertise of the smaller agency in return of either tooling expertise,
knowledge or raw intelligence.
Finally we have what most of us are familiar with because of the amount of information
that's out there which is large countries with hundreds or thousands of people dedicated
to cyber signals intelligence with global presence typically with centers in multiple
parts of their countries and in some cases even in remote countries to have 24x7 coverage
for all of the operations.
Those organizations as you can imagine they are so big that they have varying technical
expertise they might have areas of the agency where they have extremely technically capable
people and other areas where people are not so competent but because of the size of those
organizations they tend to be very bureaucratic which means you have multiple layers of management
you have different organizations duplicating work of other organizations because there
is miscommunication due to the amount of abstraction layers in between and so on so this is a disadvantage
since those organizations tend to be a little bit slower on how they operate.
Typically because of their size and their capabilities they are building a lot of things
in-house and there is a bias towards insourcing and this has a logic behind it since those
organizations cannot reach out and get a lot of their needs from what is available by third
parties.
Of course they have some sort of collaboration but it is a different kind of collaboration
they typically have much smaller amount of countries that they are very closely collaborating
with and a way larger amount of countries that they are acting as a service provider.
Now in terms of people in those organizations you can easily probably imagine this a lot
of people see that as a normal job so there is nothing special to it other people love
it and some people don't like it.
This reflects also to the way they work so you could see that certain people are far
more engaged and they are doing really innovative work while others are doing a playbook like
step by step.
Like any other organization whether in the private or public sector there is some form
of performance evaluation which means people are not focused always on how to get the best
thing out there but how to do the best for their performance evaluation.
This depends from one agency to another but it's something that you need to consider and
all of the organizations have some form of KPIs it could be as simple as how many teachers
did you fulfill from the collections that you requested to do all the way to did you
manage to compromise any of our technology because of the operations you executed so
there are many different ways that people are getting measured but the most important
part you have to remember is the last one that each agency has its own culture which
means some agencies might be very bureaucratic very top-down and very structured while others
might be more like a startup company on how they operate and that also reflects on the
way they are doing cyber operations and all of us as defenders the way we see them when
they are attacking different networks.
The last part that I have from this introduction is this one which is how those organizations
are structured.
Basically you have one part of the agency which is responsible for all of the incoming
requests you are talking about people that are like liaison officers in other agencies
other people that are receiving all of the incoming RFIs the request for information
and so on this is the let's say ingestion for the intelligence requirements what do
the customer need from this agency the largest part by far in most organizations is the analysis
and production this is where you have all of your intelligence analysts that their whole
job is to fulfill those priority intelligence requirements they are sitting there they have
a variety of different tools that give them access to all of the intelligence the raw
intelligence that is being collected and they are putting all of that together using various
analytic techniques to produce the intelligence products but to do that they also need the
collection and here I used also the word that NSA used to use for this department which
is data acquisition here you have the collectors the people that go out and collect the intelligence
that is needed by the analysts of course we have the strategy and leadership who is leading
this whole organization and finally a very important aspect of any intelligence agency
not just signals intelligence like in general is legal and compliance every single country
has usually a whole legal framework around those agencies and how they operate which means a lot
of the operations and general day-to-day work that is being done those agencies have to be
carefully studied and vetted to see if it fits into this legal framework the most important
part for our case is the analysis and production and collection and more importantly the collection
the collection has two sides as I mentioned previously there are some standing intelligence
requirements things that you know you have to collect and in this case it is pretty simple
that we need to have this data we go out collect them and get them to the analysts so they can get
their job done but then imagine that you are an analyst you are trying to fulfill a PIR and you
realize you're missing some information then what do you do is you go and create a task this is
called testing and it might be like I was looking for eggs but we don't have it here is a task to
find the collected this is the second part of the collection which is testing the first is you have
those requirements you know where to find them you go and fetch them the second is I have an
intelligence gap please go out and fill it now there are a couple of different ways that the
collection could be done one is through the automated bulk collection for example at the
moment I think there is not even a single country that doesn't have something similar to what it was
released like 10 years ago with prism of the NSA every single country that I'm aware of has a
program where their country's intelligence agency has hardware inside of the country's ISPs that
they can use to monitor traffic this is an automated bulk collection they can enable at
any time they want they can collect as much information as they are legally allowed to do
the second part is that a lot of countries are operating botnets like last summer in a
black hat BlackBerry threat intelligence revealed that the Linux XOR botnet is actually operated
by Chinese nation-state actors and China is not the only country that operates a botnet and that
is the automated part that is continuously running it is a continuous effort by the collection teams
to keep that up to date to maintain it and have this flow of information then we have the tailored
access which is some information that it is only available in a very specific source and you need
some sort of targeted tailored access to get there and again there are many examples of that like
most of the really impressive cyber espionage operations that we see in the news and in threat
research fall into that space and then we have a very interesting space that I'm going to be
talking about later which is the fourth party collection and I have a whole section about it
later on okay so now that we have all a good idea how those organizations are typically structured
how they operate and their general approaches let's see what happens when threat research is
released whether this is a threat report or let's say some zero day that is being leaked what
happens and it won't be surprising to anyone hopefully the first thing that happens is a
retrospective why did this happen what can we learn from it the retrospective results into lessons
learned and in some cases into counterintelligence operations let me give you some concrete examples
here I will start with the first two parts of the retrospective and lessons learned if you
remember in Wikileaks there was a major leak a couple of years ago from from the CIA called the
vault 7 what I'm going to be picking up from there is one of their confluence wiki pages inside the
CIA you have a few different directorates and one of them is the DI the digital innovation
in the digital innovation we have the information operations center or IOC in there we have an
engineering department that they are building a lot of hudging tools that they are known as the
EDG or engineering development group and in that engineering development group there is a small
group of very senior developers engineers and some of the leadership which called TAC or T-A-C
which the technical advisory council and as you can imagine the TAC is responsible for exactly
that providing technical advices now in the Wikileaks content there was a very interesting
case and it was this one if you remember in 2015 Kaspersky labs created a very detailed report
about the equation group that included a lot of the tools that they were using how those tools
were related to each other and more or less the equation group as a threat actor now this is a
screenshot from this internal wiki page that was leaked by Wikileaks and what do we read over here
is what did equation do wrong and how can we avoid doing the same in there there are very interesting
comments and how the wiki structured in Wikileaks is that you have a user and then a number of each
user so those are different employees of the technical advisory council and the EDG of the
CIA that are discussing the results of the retrospective and they documented them in a wiki
page in there we read a few different things for example one of the identified issues was that they
were using a customized crypto that was allowing Kaspersky labs to easily detect them through
different tooling that they were deploying and the proposed solution from TAC was to use
available crypto like Microsoft's libraries OpenSSL, PolarSSL and so on
another finding that TAC had in their lessons learned was the unique mutexes being used
and their proposal was to change their compiling to issue a warning anytime such a mutex is
generated and record those mutexes so they can know which mutex was used in which operation so
the next time some threat research is published they can quickly go back and see which operation
might be compromised the same with the PDP strings that they were hard-coded in the binaries and the
TAC had a very interesting suggestion here which is to create a scanner that will be looking for
those and cross-correlating them with internal sources such as active directory for usernames
and other information the most important issue that I want to highlight is the last one which is
the reuse of exploits and the reason why I want to highlight this one is because of what you might be
hearing as the IC the intelligence community every single country no matter how small or big it is
it's going to have some form of intelligence community when we are talking about large
countries like the United States officially there are 17 intelligence agencies in the intelligence
community and that is even bigger as you can probably imagine all of this is called the
community because those agencies are sharing different technologies and expertise and
information between them one of that is exploits again using that information from wiki leaks
we can find this in a wiki page this is a subset of the iOS exploits that the US intelligence
community had available at the time of that leak and what I want you to pay extra attention at
this column over here it says found by here we can see that some of them were found by
US organizations like the NSA the FBI's remote operations unit the CIA some of them were
purchased by some of the third parties I mentioned earlier companies that are building and offering
those to governments but there are also some from foreign intelligence agencies like the GCHQ in
this case which is one of the bigger allies of the United States for us as defenders this is critical
information since because you saw an exploit being used in an operation by threat actor A
it doesn't mean that this is the only threat actor that had access to it or that was the
threat actor that discovered it but let me go into a little bit more detail in this topic
if we look into the comments of this thread in this wiki page about the retrospective of the
equation group we can learn more about how those organizations work when there is a leak like that
in a threat research here we read that the custom crypto is more of NSA failing to its own internal
policies and standards which came about in response to prior problems and we read that in the past
there were crypto issues where people used zero initialization vectors and other misconfiguration
as a result the NSA crypto guys blessed one library as the correct implementation and everyone was
told to use that now as a defender and especially as a threat researchers this is very useful to know
since you might see a very advanced new malware that is still using one library that doesn't make
any sense but that library is also used in another malware from the same threat actor and that could
be your connecting link between the two of them and the reason could be as simple as this one
it could be literally a policy or a standard of that organization but everyone must use this
specific library of course this is not the only case but it's a nice example to keep in mind
another very interesting comment is this one especially the second sentence of this comment it
says the shared code appears to be the largest single factor is allowing Kaspersky labs to tie
all of these tools together the acquisition and use of command control domains was probably number
two on the list and I'm sure the COG infrastructure people are paying attention to this
here we have another comment which is about the reuse of code and again some of it might be
because of some standard or a policy and some of that could be because that code was available
and again think about like this you are a developer in a large organization
you might have complete different departments dealing with one area like let's say
protocol communication or encryption or authentication and you just reuse that
code to your own library and if we are talking about a large intelligence community
you might have multiple agencies using parts of this code and as a third researcher this is a
very useful component to start attributing all of these activities to a single nation
of course to narrow it down from a nation to a specific agency it's a whole new level of
attribution that requires different kinds of techniques now another very interesting comment
is this one I'm quite sure that a lot of people and I also did it for some time were referring to
the equation group as the NSA but here we read actually from people working in the US intelligence
community in the CIA in this case that the way I was looking at it the equation group isn't the
single group Kaspersky imagines it to be so basically it is the tools that seem to make
the combusting group and that follows up also in another comment from the same user that happened
a little bit earlier that provides us a better understanding of that it says the equation group
as labeled in the report does not relate to a specific group but rather a collection of tools
mostly from the NSA's tailored access operations and the CIA's information operations center
so basically the attribution that we had from Kaspersky labs as the equation group being a single
threat actor translates to the US intelligence community as a whole with more focus on the cyber
units of the CIA and the NSA and this is fully understandable since it is very hard to differentiate
when you have such strong collaboration between intelligence agencies hopefully that gives you an
idea of what's going on in an intelligence agency when you have threat research being published or
being leaked but I also mentioned about counterintelligence operations and let's take a few
examples over here I guess all of us are familiar with this one that's one of the diagrams that
FireEye released for the SolarWinds operation that happened at the end of 2020 and the beginning of
2021 and do you remember some of the top targets of this threat actor if you don't I will name a few
one of them was FireEye another one was CrowdStrike another was Palo Alto Networks
another one was Malwarebytes, Microsoft, Cisco Security and in all of those cases what was the
adversary after they were after threat research and tooling that those organizations were using
this means that they had an intelligence requirement or they might just be executing a
counterintelligence operation which means what do all of these companies know about us what is the
information that they have and this is not surprising if we go a little bit further back in
2015 we have this case which is known as the Dooku 2.0 from Kaspersky Labs which again a nation-state
actor infiltrated Kaspersky Lab purely to steal threat research and if we go even more closely
like recently the last couple of weeks that could happen actually the last month and even earlier
this month released by Google's Threat Analysis Group which is a North Korean threat actors
targeting threat researchers specifically in this case exploit developers and vulnerability
researchers to obtain some of the zero days that they might not have and those are not the only
cases in one of his interviews in 2019 Edward Snowden stated that the way NSA was working when
he was at the NSA was that they were buying any sort of threat research that was available to them
and that that wasn't available to them they were stealing it so this is what some of these
organizations might also be doing and that could be a clear sign of the counterintelligence
operation to find out what the threat researchers know about them.
Now I'm moving to the second section of my presentation the attribution I mentioned that
the attribution for a nation-state is not as simple as any cyber security organization that
might not have to defend it in a national level and why is this the case let's pick up some real
cases that happened in the last couple of years some of you might remember this one that goes
some of you might remember this one that goes when a Turla APT group which is known as a Russian
APT group probably associated with the FSB hacked into one of the Iran's APT group's
infrastructure a command control server that is attributed to the APT-34 and used it to infect
the machines that were connected to the command control server with the Turla's APT implants
that sounded initially quite impressive but really it is not something unusual and I'm going
to be talking about it more in this section but this is not the only case why attribution is hard
think about this case and this is just another example from Intel 471 a public post that they
made last year where they have clear links of North Korea threat actors being collaboration
with Russian-speaking cyber criminals for a quite simple reason let's say for example that
a cyber crime group that operates a malware like let's say trick bot emote it like it doesn't
matter they have access to one of the targets that you want to get access if your legal framework
allows it why waste all of this time to infiltrate the target instead of just buying the access that
someone already has now us as defenders when we see a commodity malware infection we might not
treat it as nation-state infiltration but as we see over here it could clearly be a nation-state
infiltration let's complicate the matters even more do you remember this one from 2019 this is
a blog post from FireEye saying that APT-41 has a dual espionage and cyber crime operation
and specifically this APT group from China has been observed in multiple occasions doing this
kind of work like in the normal office hours the operators are doing what the Chinese nation-state
wants them to do and after their work they use the same knowledge skills and in some case even
tooling for cyber crime operations so where do you draw the line you know where can you attribute
what is which nation okay let me talk a little bit about this case about the fourth party
collection or what Terla APT group did with APT-34 in 2017 in 2015 Der Spiegel leaked a slide deck
from the NSA talking about exactly this technique and the slide deck was from 2011 so literally here
we are talking about a technique that is known nation-state actors for at least 10 years
it is called the fourth party collection and it goes like this the first part is the passive
collection this is a screenshot from the slide deck so think about it this came from the NSA
so the US is marked in green color on the left what we see here is that some foreign government
managed to infiltrate into some systems which is the systems you see on the bottom
the foreign computer network exploitation victims and they are infected with malware
that talks to the command and control server in between of course there is a proxy layer
to hide the real command and control what the NSA said over here is that the first step is
the passive acquisition which means at the network tab between that middle layer and
the command and control and what the NSA did at that stage is monitor what is being exfiltrated
and if that is something of interest then you can move to the next stage and the next stage
is the active acquisition this is the exploitation of that middle layer and maybe even the command
and control layer so you can have full control of what goes through those channels and either
divert it or steal what might be interesting to you to cover your intelligence requirements
but that goes a bit further we are only talking okay we move from passive acquisition to
active acquisition the next one is victim stealing or sharing and what happens here is that
exactly what we read that Terlaptit group did in 2017 that is since you have access to the
command and control server or the intermediate proxy layer you can either use the already
infected devices to issue some commands let's say for example that they have a malware that allows
command execution you can say okay that infected system also has this file that are interested
to my agency let me request that and get those files to my agency or you could use it to deploy
your own implant in there which exactly what Terla group did with APT34's infrastructure in 2017
they deployed their own implant again this is something from 2011 and why I want to highlight
it here is that when you are working in such an agency and your whole job is data acquisition
as the NSA calls it or data collection your brainstorming will be around topics like this one
how can you get information without being detected by hiding as much of your activity as possible
and of course the last step of this collection is the repurposing and if I remember correctly what
the NSA did in this case it was that they exfiltrated the exploits and the malware that
an Iranian nation-state actor was using they reverse engineered it and then they build their
own version of it so that they can use it in their own cyber operations that is also very useful for
that research since a lot of times you might see a variant of a known malware and if you
studied carefully you can start realizing that this is a reverse engineered product this is a
product that resulted from another malware that someone took reverse engineered adjusted to their
needs and released it to the wild so if this is so complex and there are so many ways to hide
your presence how can you actually do attribution and once again I will be using some leaked
information here in 2016 reality winner a former NSA employee leaked this slide deck to the press
this is a slide deck that shows an operation from the GRU the Russian Military Intelligence Agency
against the US government but what is important for us in this talk over here is how did the NSA
manage to attribute this attack to the GRU and what can we learn from it so I will take
a small snapshot of this very detailed diagram and let's see how they did it
so the legend you can see on the on the bottom it is pretty self-explanatory and
we only have a small part of the whole diagram which is the adversary space
and the neutral space and here we have the operators that registered with a personal
cell phone one account and that was a gmail account in this case and then they sent a test
email to their personal account then they connected to a system which the NSA refers to as the ORB
operational relay box and from there they started using those similar addresses to deliver the
spear phishing campaign using this information the NSA was able to link it with a cyber organization
within the GRU or the General Staff Main Intelligence Directorate of Russia
there is also a quick description that it is unknown if the GRU was able to successfully
compromise any of the entities targeted as part of this campaign while this the name of the unit
cyber espionage program utilized some techniques that were similar to other Russian GRU cyber
operations units this activity demonstrated several characteristics that distinguish it
from another major GRU spear phishing program known as and then the name of the program
now what is this telling us? it is telling us that the NSA had access to the gmail accounts
that were used for the spear phishing campaign which is reasonable to think and or they had access
to passive network collection and by that I mean network tabs where they could see the traffic that
we see displayed over here and of course they had a way to map that the phone numbers that were
linked to the email accounts they were linked to a GRU operator and you might be thinking whoa that
is impossible for me as a threat researcher to have this kind of access this kind of information
but I beg to differ over here because if you are defending a network you most likely have most of
these components and you might be thinking yeah but I don't have like a full inventory of GRU
operators phone numbers to cross correlate if this phone number that they have seen in an attack is
related to an actual nation state actor and the truth is that there is so much data being released
every day from data breaches from leaked information from misconfigurations that using some
simple ocean techniques you might be able to build some of these capabilities for your organization
and eventually it is not that hard to do this kind of correlations the most important factor in this
one is the timing that the NSA was able to bind this activity with the time that the spear phishing
campaign was being executed and this is how they could tie that okay the only operator that had
access to this infrastructure at that point was the GRU so it has to be the GRU that did this
operation as it was shown in previous examples nation state actors are in this continuous
spy versus spy trying to take over one's command and control infrastructure so when you're doing
attribution you have to consider the timing and you also have to consider other factors
infrastructure itself doesn't say anything you have to consider who was operating this
infrastructure and with that I will move to a more recent example in January 5th as you probably know
the U.S. government was kind of forced to make a statement around the SolarWinds case
and for this reason there was this joint statement that was released to the public by multiple
agencies including the FBI the Office of Director of National Intelligence and the NSA with the most
important part for our talk being this one they state likely Russian in origin and now you probably
understand why they didn't say anything more strong like it was this unit from Russia or it
was Russian activity and they say likely Russian activity because as we know today the U.S.
intelligence community was getting forced to make a statement and probably they didn't have enough
evidence to be certain about it at that stage there were some strong indications and some of them we
also know today like for example there was some code reuse between that and Terla APT group but
it is not sufficient to make an absolute statement that yeah it was definitely some Russian APT group
and this is why we see this statement that I think a lot of people were
making fun when it was released the likely Russian in origin
so for a lot of people attribution can be answered with this question who had access to the
infrastructure at the time of the cyber operation but as it was shown over here if you are a nation
state intelligence agency doing cyber sigint this is not sufficient what you want is who was
operating this infrastructure to execute this cyber operation and with that I will close this
presentation with some key takeaways that we can take from this the first one being that nation
state actors are just people doing a job with specific objectives and performance goals that
means that you might get everything from the very very engaged people that will go the extra mile
to the people that will do the bare minimum just to keep their job that also reflects to what we
see as defenders when we see those cyber operators acting inside our networks the second part is the
intention it is very hard to understand why you might be targeted and the best tip that I can
give you is keeping a close eye on geopolitical developments what do I mean by this one as I
explained in the beginning all of those agencies do not collect information just to collect
information they collect them because they have some priority intelligence requirements that they
have to fulfill they have analysts that ask for this information or they need this information to
perform their analysis for this reason if you see suddenly a country taking an adversarial step
towards another country you should be expecting that that also reflects to their cyber operations
the same with your organization if your organization holds information that could
be valuable for a country that suddenly has interest in this specific adversary then your
company might be part of the target list the third part is that infrastructure of an APT doesn't mean
that the same APT executed the operation or that they were interested in you it could be that you
were targeted to be used as an auxiliary let's say as an open redirection as a proxy to hide
some command control activity or something like that to send some spear phishing or it could be
that this command control infrastructure was once owned by APTA but then APTB took it over and this
is when they attacked you so although let's say you might have some reports that they say that
this infrastructure was attribute APTA in your case it might be slightly different don't make
quick judgments on that based purely on the infrastructure actually the diamond model if
you are familiar with it it was developed to remove that bias because people were making a
lot of decisions based on very specific areas around the malware being used or the infrastructure
being used the last part is that APT groups do most of their collections in bulk automated fashion
yet almost all of the research that we do focuses on tailored targeted access and I get it usually
tailored and targeted access is far more interesting since it has to be very tuned it requires a lot
of manual steps sometimes it uses very specialized implants and exploits that are developed explicitly
for this operation but if we really want to protect our organizations we have to think about
the bulk collection and what I mean by this one is that most of the countries that I have
researched on including some of the medium size and smaller size they are preferring to go after
a large telecommunication provider and see phone all of the traffic or hacking to routers into a
mobile phone operator generally go for a much bigger collection like for example what China
did with building a botnet compared to going for specific access to one company or to one person
of course both are happening and tailored and targeted access is usually far more interesting
to research on but maybe we should also start looking into the more automated collection and
how we can stop this the last point that I have is that attribution is hard hopefully that was one of
the highlights of this talk that even for nation-state actors with all of the access that
they have it is still hard to do proper attribution and for that reason we have to be thinking very
critically before we publish something as it is a general good principle in intelligence reporting
we have to be very clear about what we know what we don't know and what is our assessment and those
three things have to be very distinct so when someone reads it they can understand that okay
this threat researcher believes that this was x nation-state for this and this reason but if they
had also this information they could have really higher confidence but they don't have this
information and with that I'm closing this talk so thanks a lot everyone for attending here are
